description.narrative: PIMS 3361 CC PDF A: Preparation of Barbados' Second National Communication to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).

The project willl aid Barbados in building capacity related to climate change in Barbados, as well as the preparation of its Second National Communication to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.
independent political entity

description.narrative: ENHANCING RESILIENCE TO REDUCE VULNERABILITY IN THE CARIBBEAN

title.narrative: Enhancing Resilience to Reduce Vulnerability in the Caribbean

description.narrative: This project is designed to achieve an increased and coordinated level of risk reduction in Barbados and the OECS territories.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

HM and VA updated and supporting planning systems in the pilot countries using the real time climate monitoring systems; national PA programs for tsunami hazards advanced and implemented with the support of CTIC; enhanced national DM structures through revamped plans and active, structured community based and volunteer networks to support all phases of the DM cycle.

comment.narrative: The 10 countries (Barbados and the OECS) have all adopted the CDERA led CDM strategy. Additionally structures exist at the national and regional levels to support DM including EWS. This includes the IOC IGC system being advanced to support tsunami EWS. however it is noted that these countries have not advanced the general policies and strategies in HM and VA. Further the EWS have noted limitations and have not incorporated the advanced practices that have been successfully applied elsewhere, including Italy. The IOC IGC tsunami initiative has identified the need for a Tsunami Information Centre to support the progress made and supported in the science, communications and protocols. Whereas the Government of Barbados has offered to host the CTIC, particularly for the english speaking Caribbean and is partly functioning in this area, this area is still uncertain and in need of support.

description.narrative: OVERSEAS COUNTRIES AND TERRITORIES (OCTs) REGIONAL RISK REDUCTION INITIATIVE (R3I).

title.narrative: 00051479_Regional Risk Reduction Intiative Project Document final

description.narrative: The project seeks to address the risk of British and Dutch overseas territories by providing a network of regional infrastructure and protocols to strengthen their capacity to predict and prepare for natural hazards, improve resilience and reduce risk.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
National DM Plans and development plans informed by revised HM and VAs EWS upgraded based on best practice OCTs DM capacities assessed and capacity development strategy developed.

comment.narrative: Overseas Territories in the Caribbean region (Anguilla, Aruba, British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Montserrat, Netherlands Antilles, Turks and Caicos Islands), just as the ACP states in the Caribbean and the outermost regions of the EU in the area (Martinique and Guadeloupe), are mostly small islands, highly vulnerable to a range of natural hazards including earthquakes, hurricanes, floods landslides, tsunamis and volcanic eruptions. The islands have varying level s of capacities and successes in adopting a comprehensive approach to disaster management. These countries have relevant experiences and expertise to share with each other and also can benefit from the strategies and initiatives developed by neighbouring Caribbean countries, particularly the CDERA led Comprehensive Disaster Management Strategy.

title.narrative: Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean

description.narrative: It will focus on prevention of crime and violence by enhancing community cohesiveness and resilience through the use of multi-stakeholder dialogue, and livelihood interventions for youth through skills-training and employment opportunities.

title.narrative: Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean
Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean
Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean
Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean
Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean
Strengthening Citizen Security in the Eastern Caribbean

description.narrative: COMMUNITIES EMPOWERED AND SECURITY SECTOR INSTITUTIONS ENABLED FOR INCREASED CITIZEN SAFETY AND REDUCED LEVEL OF ARMED VIOLENCE.
Defence - policy, planning and administration

- # of evidence based community security strategies and action plans for crime and violence place and being implemented - # of countries with improved coverage of: a) community-oriented and b) gender-sensitive prevention programmes - % reduction in the homicides rates in programme countries disaggregated by gender - Existence of community multi-sectoral coordination mechanisms in programme countries - # of countries have developed and implementing citizen security policies and strategies

comment.narrative: - 0 community security strategies and action plans in place within identified communities in the Eastern Caribbean - Limited number of comprehensive crime prevention programmes in place in Barbados and the Eastern Caribbean - 1 multisectoral crime prevention mechanisms in place - 0 countries within citizen security policies and strategies in place - no data available in the Caribbean on GBV prevalence - Limited regional knowledge of citizen security - Weak national and subregional capacities for a human development approach to reducing crime and violence in the Caribbean

- # of victimisation and prevalence surveys conducted - At least (4) Crime prevention and Social Advancement networks created in Barbados and the Eastern Caribbean - # of citizen security dialogues convened in the Eastern Caribbean - # of SocialINNOV4Change project piloted in Saint Lucia - Community Security assessment methodology designed - # of community security assessment conveyed

The crime and victimisation survey has been finalised and has been tested in six (6) countries: Antigua and Barbuda, Dominica, Grenada, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.
Six (6) national citizen security dialogues were convened between May and 2015 in the following countries: Antigua and Barbuda, Dominica, Grenada, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.
The SocialINNOV4Change project has been successfully completed in 2015. All proposed activities; Ideation Workshop, Innovation Camp and Challenge have been executed. Seven (7) grants have been awarded and grantees are in the process of completing their project activities by year end.
Despite planning for the undertaking of community security assessments, these were not completed as planned. However, a survey methodology was developed and will be rolled out in 2016, pending availability of resources.

description.narrative: Strengthening resilience and coping capacities in the Caribbean through integrated early warning systems
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

% of targeted beneficiary population know and are able to identify EWS alert messages and respond in an understandable and timely way Number of end-to-end CAP EWS functioning in communities and managed by national authorities, developed using a systematised regional framework Best practices, tools and experiences for implementing CAP-based EWS articulated and disseminated through regional online platform Comprehensive regional process articulated for implementing CAP EWS based on experiences Number of new EWS case studies developed and shared on active regional knowledge platform Number of countries in the region which recognise the integrated EWS model and commit to its adoption in the future

comment.narrative: Countries do not have preparedness systems in place to effectively address the consequences of and response to natural hazards Inadequate Number of end-to-end CAP EWS functioning in communities and managed by national authorities Communities are unable to identify EWS alert messages and respond in an understandable and timely way Lack of comprehensive regional process for implementing CAP EWS No current active regional knowledge platform

1. Community assessment of vulnerability and capacities undertaken - Support to capacity building in VCA methodology in 3 countries - Conduct VCAs and EWS assessment in at least 3 communities 2. KAP surveys conducted - KAP surveys completed in 7 communities 3. Participatory system design and validation - Community and national consultations - Analysis of gender and vulnerable groups needs 4. Installation, testing and training for alerting - Site and capacity assessment in 7 communities - System design 5. Improvement and integration of hazard monitoring systems - Site assessment in 7 communities - System design - Equipment procured for beneficiary communities
- User training

Regional harmonisation and knowledge sharing for EWS Knowledge of risk and vulnerability enhanced in communities to improve preparedness and response Framework for CAP-compliant all-hazard early warning systems integrated at national and community levels

Tropical Storm Erika produced intense rainfall causing flash flooding. As of August 30, 2015, twenty persons confirmed dead. The Government has also reported 574 persons are homeless, 300 evacuated and 267 in shelters.

title.narrative: Commonwealth of Dominica Rapid Damage and Needs Assessment Final Report Oct5

description.narrative: Tropical Storm Erika produced intense rainfall causing flash flooding. As of August 30, 2015, twenty persons confirmed dead. The Government has also reported 574 persons are homeless, 300 evacuated and 267 in shelters.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Development of recovery framework in Dominica Framework endorsed by national and local authorities and CSOs working with vulnerable and most affected groups/communities Framework is gender responsive and focuses on supporting recovery of the most vulnerable/most directly impacted Framework makes recommendations for strengthening essential economic services for the reinstatement of lost livelihoods and for addressing losses in productivity Sector specific implementation plans are discussed and developed for social and economic services sectors and justice sectors Gender responsive recovery plan incorporating climate change adaptation strategies and perspectives on human security, youth, persons with vulnerabilities and indigeneous people Recovery plan which addresses social and economic loss and issues of human security

comment.narrative:
Building on experiences and lessons learnt from the 2014 PDNA in St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Saint Luica following the 2013 Christmas Trough event. Additionally national capacity in Barbados and St. Vincent and the Grenadines in PDNA built during 2015. However, given these, there is still a need to enchance capacities in the PDNA methodology in Dominica.
While there has been experience in applying the PDNA in some Eastern Caribbean countries (St. Vincent and the Grenadines; Saint Lucia) there is no coherent approach nor experience in applying the PDNA in Dominica

1 recovery plan recommendation implemented Strategy document on resettlement developed Sector specific implementation plans are discussed and developed for social and economic services sectors and justice sectors
